revision.text:
{{Infobox Organization | name = Integrating the Healthcare Enterprise | image = Integrating the Healthcare Enterprise logo.jpg | size = | alt = Big letters IHE | caption = | abbreviation = IHE | motto = | formation = 1998 | type = | status = [[Non-profit organization|Non-profit]] | purpose = | headquarters = [[Oak Brook, Illinois]] | leader_title = | leader_name = | key_people = | website = {{URL|www.ihe.net}} }}
'''Integrating the Healthcare Enterprise''' ('''IHE''') is a non-profit organization based in the US state of [[Illinois]].<ref>{{Cite web |title= Governance |work= Integrating the Healthcare Enterprise web site |url= http://www.ihe.net/Governance/ |accessdate= August 4, 2013 }}</ref> It sponsors an initiative by the [[healthcare industry]] to improve the way computer systems share information. IHE was established in 1998 by a consortium of [[radiologists]] and [[information technology]] (IT) experts.
==Operations== IHE created and operates a process through which [[interoperability]] of health care IT systems can be improved. The group gathers case requirements, identifies available standards, and develops technical guidelines which manufacturers can implement. IHE also stages "connectathons" and "interoperability showcases" in which vendors assemble to demonstrate the interoperability of their products.<ref>{{Cite journal |title= Integrating the Healthcare Enterprise: A Primer: Part 4. The Role of Existing Standards in IHE |author1=Michael Henderson |author2=Fred M. Behlen |author3=Charles Parisot |author4=Eliot L. Siegel |author5=David S. Channin |journal= RadioGraphics |volume=21 |number= 6 |date= 2001 |pages= 1597–1603 |url= http://radiographics.rsna.org/content/21/6/1597.full |accessdate= August 4, 2013 |doi=10.1148/radiographics.21.6.g01nv261597|pmid=11706228 }} and so all</ref>
==Sponsorship== {{Refimprove section|date=January 2017}} IHE is sponsored by the [[Healthcare Information and Management Systems Society]] (HIMSS), the [[Radiological Society of North America]] (RSNA), and the [[American College of Cardiology]] (ACC). The [[eye care]] domain is sponsored by the [[American Academy of Ophthalmology]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Who is IHE?|url=http://www.ihe.net/FAQ/#Who_is_IHE?|website=IHE.net|accessdate=30 January 2017}}</ref>
==Projects== IHE integration profiles describe a clinical information need or [[workflow]] scenario and document how to use established [[standardization|standards]] to accomplish it. A group of systems that implement the same integration profile address the need/scenario in a mutually compatible way.
For example, the [[Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine]] (DICOM) standards specify many different formats for image data. A given set of images that might comply with some optional parts of the standards might still not be accepted by an application in use by a particular radiologist. Profiles reduce the chances of these incompatibilities.<ref>{{Cite journal |title= Image Exchange: IHE and the Evolution of Image Sharing |author1=David S. Mendelson |author2=Peter R. G. Bak |author3=Elliot Menschik |author4=Eliot Siegel |date= November 2008 |journal= RadioGraphics |volume= 28 |issue=7 |pages= 1817–1833 |doi= 10.1148/rg.287085174 |pmid=18772272 |url= http://radiographics.rsna.org/content/28/7/1817.full |accessdate= August 4, 2013 }}</ref>
The [[Logical Observation Identifiers Names and Codes]] (LOINC) standard codes for use in [[database]]s are often used in IHE profiles.<ref>{{Cite web |title= HL7/LOINC Document Ontology: Proposed Revision |author= Kevin Coonan |publisher= Deloitte Consulting |date= August 30, 2012 |work= Presentation for LOINC meeting |url= http://loinc.org/meetings/20120830/LOINC_DocOnt_Description.pdf |accessdate= August 4, 2013 }}</ref>
A model for [[Cross Enterprise Document Sharing|cross-enterprise document sharing]] called [[Cross Enterprise Document Sharing|XDS]] allows hospitals to share electronic records that use the [[Health Level 7]] (HL7) standards and LOINC codes.<ref>{{Cite book |title= Design and Implementation of the System Architecture for Sharing Medical Information Based on HL7-CDA among Hospitals by the XDS Model of IHE |author1=Bong-Mun Jang |author2=Joong Il Kim |author3=Keon Ho Yang |author4=Dong Hoon Han |author5=Hyo Min Cho |author6=Haijo Jung |author7=Hee-Joung Kim |date= August 27, 2006 |journal= World Congress of Medical Physics and Biomedical Engineering |publisher= Springer |volume= 14 |pages= 460–1833 |doi= 10.1007/978-3-540-36841-0_123 |isbn= 978-3-540-36841-0 |url= https://link.springer.com/content/pdf/10.1007/978-3-540-36841-0_123.pdf |accessdate= August 4, 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title= LOINC® Document Ontology Proposed Extension and Revision |date= July 24, 2012 |work= LOINC meeting material |url= http://loinc.org/meetings/20120830/2012%2008%20-%20LOINC_DocOnt_Description.pdf |accessdate= August 4, 2013 }}</ref> The [[United States Department of Veterans Affairs]] revised its plans in 1999 to adopt IHE recommendations.<ref>{{Cite web |title= Modality Interface DICOM Conformance Requirements Version 1.2 |date= September 7, 1999 |author= Herman Oosterwijk, Dezso Csipo, Ruth E. Dayhoff, Daniel N. Carozza M. Elon Gale, and Eliot Siegel |url= http://www.mevis-research.de/~meyer/dicom/va_modalityspec_1.2.pdf |accessdate= August 4, 2013 }}</ref>
IHE integration statements are prepared and published by a vendor to list the IHE profiles supported by a specific release of a specific product.
IHE technical frameworks are detailed documents which specify the integration profiles and associated actors (systems) and transactions.<ref>{{Cite journal |title= IHE: integrating the healthcare enterprise, towards complete integration of healthcare information systems |vauthors=Bernardini A, Alonzi M, Campioni P, Vecchioli A, Marano P |pmid= 14509182 |date= January–March 2003 |journal= Rays |volume= 28 |number=1 |pages= 83–93 }}</ref>
IHE connectathons are annual events where equipment vendors bring products with IHE profiles and test them with other vendors.<ref>{{Cite web |title= IHE PCD Connectathon – Is Your Vendor There? |work= Medical Connectivity |author= Tim Gee |date= January 29, 2008 |url= http://medicalconnectivity.com/2008/01/29/ihe-pcd-connectathon-is-your-vendor-there/ |accessdate= August 4, 2013 }}</ref> The events are held in Europe, USA, Korea, Japan and Australia.<ref>{{cite web|last1=MacIsaac|first1=Peter|title=IHE Connectathon Results Browser|url=http://connectathon-results.ihe.net/|website=IHE Connectathon results|publisher=IHE|accessdate=2017-12-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=MacIsaac|first1=Peter|title=IHE Asia-Pacific - 2008 Connectathon Results|url=http://www.ihe.net.au/Results.htm|website=IHE Australia|accessdate=27 February 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |title= Big Iron meets Big Data |work= European Hospital |date= May 22, 2013 |url= http://www.european-hospital.com/en/article/10742-Big_Iron_meets_Big_Data.html |accessdate= August 4, 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |title=IHE European Connectathon: Cross-border network expands |work= European Hospital |date= June 14, 2012 |url= http://www.european-hospital.com/en/article/9763-IHE_European_Connectathon_Cross-border_network_expands.html |accessdate= August 4, 2013 }}</ref> The term "connectathon" was coined in the 1980s by [[Sun Microsystems]] for similar vendor-neutral interoperability testing of the [[Network File System]] protocols and related technologies.<ref>{{Cite web |title= What is Connectathon? |work= Original Connectathon.Org web site |url= http://www.connectathon.org/ |deadurl=yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/19990128152940/http://www.connectathon.org/#whatis |archivedate= January 28, 1999 }}</ref> The first NFS Connectathon was held in 1985.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Calaghan|first1=Brent|title=NFS Illustrated|date=2000|publisher=Addison-Wesley|page=252|url=https://books.google.com/?id=OnuVyuk9bjgC&pg=PA252&lpg=PA252&dq=nfs+connectathon+1985#v=onepage&q=nfs%20connectathon%201985&f=|accessdate=27 February 2016|isbn=9780321618931}}</ref>
In 2008, an agreement was announced for cooperation with the [[Continua Health Alliance]].<ref>{{Cite news |title= Continua and the IHE Collaborate to Strengthen Outreach and Message |date= October 28, 2008 |work= News release |publisher= Continua Health Alliance |url= http://www.continuaalliance.org/node/199 |accessdate= August 4, 2013 }}</ref>
In 2012, a guide was published on access to health data from [[mobile devices]].<ref>{{Cite news |title= IHE releases draft implementation guide for mobile access to health data |work= Mobi Health News |date= June 8, 2013 |author= Neil Versel |url= http://mobihealthnews.com/17669/ihe-releases-draft-implementation-guide-for-mobile-access-to-health-data/ |accessdate= August 4, 2013}}</ref>
Although in 2004 an estimate was that complete interoperability could be completed in ten years, by 2013 results were still mixed.<ref>{{Cite news |title= Interoperability in its 'last mile'? |date= February 19, 2013 |work= Healthcare IT News |url= http://www.healthcareitnews.com/news/interoperability-its-last-mile |accessdate= August 4, 2013 }}</ref>
In 2013, co-chairs were David Mendelson, director of clinical informatics at [[Mount Sinai Medical Center]]<ref>{{Cite news |title= Mount Sinai starts teleradiology program |url= http://www.healthcareitnews.com/news/mount-sinai-starts-teleradiology-program |accessdate= August 4, 2013 }}</ref> and Elliot B. Sloane of the Center for Healthcare Information Research and Policy and research professor at [[Drexel University]].<ref>{{Cite web |title= Wireless in Healthcare Issues & Lessons Learned |author= Elliot B. Sloane |date= July 26, 2010 |work= Presentation for AAMI |url= http://www.aami.org/meetings/wireless/materials/Sloane.pdf |accessdate= August 4, 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title= Elliot B. Sloane, Ph.D |work= Faculty profile |url= http://www.biomed.drexel.edu/new04/content/academics/faculty/dsp_faculty_details.cfm?RECID=294 |accessdate= August 4, 2013 }}</ref>

{{No footnotes|date=April 2018}} The '''International Headache Society''' ('''IHS''') is a [[charitable organization|charity]] membership organisation founded in 1981 for those with a professional commitment to helping people affected by [[headache]].
It has over 1,000 ordinary members (including national society members). The society publishes an international journal ''[[Cephalalgia (journal)|Cephalalgia]]''. The society was incorporated in 1994 in England and Wales as a Company Limited by Guarantee and registered in 1995 as a charity.
==International Headache Congress== The International Headache Congress (IHC) is held every second year, organized and hosted on behalf of IHS by a member national society.
==References== {{reflist|30em}}

'''James Roderick Johnston Cameron''' [[Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh|PPRCSE]] (1902–1997) was a 20th century Scottish surgeon who served as President of the [[Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh]] from 1967 to 1970.
==Life== [[File:The grave of James Roderick Johnston Cameron, Grange Cemetery.jpg|thumb|The grave of James Roderick Johnston Cameron, Grange Cemetery]] He was born on 24 June 1902 in [[Belfast]]<ref>http://www.ancestryresearchservice.com/genealogy/familygroup.php?familyID=F1781&tree=cameron1</ref> the son of a dentist of Scottish descent, and originally trained as a dentist.
He studied Medicine at [[Edinburgh University]] and did postgraduate studies at the [[University of Montreal]] and [[McGill University]] developing an interest in [[neurosurgery]] under Prof [[Wilder Penfield]]. Returning to Britain he became an assistant surgeon at [[Leith Hospital]] then in 1939 got a position at [[Edinburgh Royal Infirmary]]. At the outbreak of the [[Second World War]] he joined the [[Royal Army Medical Corps]]. He landed at [[Narvik]] following the [[D-Day landings]]. A hand injury prevented him from operating and he was posted to the [[Chasseurs Alpins]] (Les Diables Bleu) as their Medical Officer. He returned to Edinburgh after the war and specialised in [[thyroid]] treatment.<ref>British Medical Journal, obituary 6 Sept 1997</ref>
He died in [[Edinburgh]] on 23 February 1997. He is buried in [[Grange Cemetery]]. The simple stone lies in the south-west section.
==Family==
In 1940, just prior to going to war, he was married to Dorothy Margaret Pearson (1913-1995).<ref>Grave of J R J Cameron, Grange Cemetery</ref> She was an artist and her portrait of James is held in the Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh.<ref>https://artuk.org/discover/artworks/james-roderick-johnston-cameron-19021997-frcsed-1931-prcsed-19671970-187222</ref> They had two sons and two daughters.

'''Judith Elizabeth Hall''' {{post-nominals|country=GBR|OBE}} is Professor of Anaesthetics, Intensive Care and Pain Medicine at [[Cardiff University]]. She leads the Phoenix Project, a Cardiff University partnership with the [[University of Namibia]] that seeks to reduce poverty, promote health and support sustainable environmental development.
== Career == Professor Hall is a Consultant anaesthetist at [[Cardiff and Vale University Health Board]], Director of MediWales, a life science network for Wales, and a council member for the [[Royal College of Anaesthetists]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.cardiff.ac.uk/people/view/126363-hall-judith|title=Professor Judith Hall – People – Cardiff University|work=Cardiff University|access-date=2018-09-07|language=en}}</ref>
Hall is the founder of the charity Mothers of Africa<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-wales-17438514|title=Reducing maternal death in Africa|last=Prior|first=Neil|date=2012-03-25|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-09-07|language=en-GB}}</ref> and through her charity work is contributing to the improvement of maternal mortality in sub-Saharan Africa.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cardiff.ac.uk/news/view/47303-new-year-honours|title=New Year Honours|work=Cardiff University|access-date=2018-09-07|language=en}}</ref>
In 2006 she developed the first medical simulation suite in Cardiff University's School of Medicine.<ref name=":0" />
In 2011 Hall developed a device to prevent potentially fatal 'wrong-route' injections of drugs into wrong parts of the body, making use of colour-coded and shaped connectors that are designed to be used in only one area.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-wales-12608471|title=Prof invents jabs safety device|date=2011-03-01|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-09-07|language=en-GB}}</ref>
Her research degree was awarded by the [[Cardiff University School of Medicine|University of Wales, College of Medicine]].<ref name=":2" />
=== Phoenix Project === Professor Hall leads Cardiff University’s Phoenix Project in collaboration with the [[University of Namibia]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://bcbinusa.com/uncategorized/trauma-pack-to-save-countless-lives/|title=Trauma pack to save ‘countless lives’ - BCB International USA|website=bcbinusa.com|language=en|access-date=2018-09-07}}</ref> This engagement project works with communities in Cardiff and beyond, particularly in Namibia, on projects in health, education and poverty reduction.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/wales-news/full-list-welsh-heroes-campaigners-14296605|title=The Welsh heroes, stars and campaigners up for St David Awards|last=Deacon|first=Thomas|date=2018-02-16|work=walesonline|access-date=2018-09-08}}</ref> It has 40 sub-projects, including doctor and nurse education, developing the software sector in Namibia, work around the value of culture and languages in young people, and enabling police and ambulance services to save lives in road traffic collisions.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cardiff.ac.uk/phoenix-project/about|title=About – Phoenix Project|last=|first=|date=|work=Cardiff University|access-date=2018-09-08|language=en}}</ref>
In October 2018 Hall and Dr Brian Jenkins will deliver specialist nurse training in Namibia which is unavailable across much of southern Africa, including post-operative pain management, interpreting blood results, and monitoring the respiratory system. It is the first specialist nurse training outside midwifery in Namibia. Hall was personally asked to set up the specialist nurse training by Namibia’s deputy minister of health and social services Hon [[Julieta Kavetuna]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.wales.nhs.uk/news/42951|title=NHS Wales {{!}} Medical experts will travel more than 5,000 miles to Namibia to provide life-saving training|last=CVUHB|first=Cardiff & Vale University Health Board -|website=www.wales.nhs.uk|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-09-07}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nursingtimes.net/news/education/african-specialist-nurse-training-will-transform-care/7011422.article|title=Welsh specialist nurse training will ‘transform care’ in Africa|work=Nursing Times|access-date=2018-09-07|language=en}}</ref>
== Honours and awards == Hall was a [[Welsh Woman of the Year]] 2008-9.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.walesonline.co.uk/lifestyle/showbiz/welsh-woman-year-judith-halls-2142564|title=Welsh Woman of the Year Judith Hall’s African challenge|last=Hamburgh|first=Rin|date=2008-11-29|work=walesonline|access-date=2018-09-07}}</ref> In 2011 Hall was awarded the MediWales NHS Award for Innovation working with Industry, MediWales Industry Award for Innovation, Insider Wales Innovation Wales Award, and a Personal Recognition Award for Contribution to Patient Safety from the Welsh Government.<ref name=":0" />
In 2013 Hall was awarded an [[Order of the British Empire|OBE]] in the [[New Year Honours]] List, for services to academic anaesthesia and charitable services in Africa.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/honours-list/9768920/New-Year-Honours-2013-full-list-of-recipients.html|title=New Year Honours 2013: full list of recipients|date=2012-12-29|access-date=2018-09-07|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}}</ref>
She is Project Lead on the Phoenix Project, which won International Collaboration of the Year in the [[Times Higher Education]] Awards in 2017. The project won a [[St David Awards|St David Award]] in 2018, which recognises exceptional achievements of people and groups in Wales.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.myscience.org.uk/wire/phoenix_project_shortlisted_for_major_award-2018-cardiff|title=Phoenix Project shortlisted for major award|last=2018|first=|date=|website=www.myscience.org.uk|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-09-07}}</ref> The award was presented by [[First Minister of Wales|First Minister]] [[Carwyn Jones]] at the [[Senedd]] in Cardiff.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cardiff.ac.uk/medicine/news/remedy/10-ways-medic-is-making-an-impact|title=10 ways Medic is making an impact|last=|first=|date=|work=Cardiff University|access-date=2018-09-07|language=en}}</ref>
In July 2018 Hall was awarded an [[Honorary fellowship|Honorary Fellowship]] by the [[University of Wales Trinity Saint David]], at a graduation ceremony in [[Brangwyn Hall]] in Swansea, Wales.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://www.uwtsd.ac.uk/news/press-releases/press-2018/professor-judith-hall-obe-receives-honorary-fellowship.html|title=Press Releases 2018 – University of Wales Trinity Saint David|last=UWTSD|first=Web Development Team -|website=www.uwtsd.ac.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-09-07}}</ref>

revision.comment: Link corrected from West Manych to East Manych.
revision.text:
{{coord|44|49|N|44|47|E|display=title}} The '''Kuma–Manych Canal''' ({{lang-ru|Кумо–Манычский канал}}) is an [[irrigation]] [[canal]] in Russia's [[Stavropol Krai]]. The canal, completed in 1965,<ref name=kuma>[http://www.vladsc.narod.ru/library/stavrop/prikumie.htm Kuma Region Irrigation] {{ru icon}}</ref> runs across the [[Kuma–Manych Depression]], connecting the [[Kuma River (Russia)|Kuma River]], which flows into the [[Caspian Sea]], with the [[East Manych|East Manych River]], which also flows toward the Caspian, but dries out long before reaching it. The East Manych River should not be confused with the [[Manych River|West Manych]], a tributary of the [[Don River (Russia)|Don]] which flows into the [[Sea of Azov]] and connects to the [[Black Sea]].
The Kuma–Manych Canal begins near the village of Novokumsky on the Kuma River, between the cities of [[Budyonnovsk]] and [[Neftekumsk]]. Its starting point is at a small reservoir on the Kuma River ({{coord|44|48|10|N|44|39|40|E|name=start}}) into which the [[Terek–Kuma Canal]] (Терско–Кумский канал; completed 1958<ref name=kuma/>) brings the [[Terek River|Terek]] water from the south. From there, the Kuma–Manych Canal carries water first toward the north-east, and then toward the north-west, ending at the southern shore of the [[Chogray Reservoir]] on the [[East Manych]] River; Google maps show a [[River delta|small peninsula, formed by the alluvial deposits]] at the canal's end point there ({{coord|45|27|50|N|44|37|33|E|name=end}}).
== Other proposed canals in the area == In June 2007, the leaders of [[Kazakhstan]] suggested that Russia build a much deeper canal (dubbed [[Eurasia Canal]]) along the bottom of the Kuma–Manych Depression, suitable for large-ship navigation between the [[Caspian Sea]] and the [[Black Sea]]. The [[Kazakhstan Academy of Sciences]] started conducting a review of possible routes.<ref>[http://www.businessweek.com/globalbiz/content/jul2007/gb2007079_528939.htm Caspian Canal Could Boost Kazakh Trade] [[Business Week]].</ref>
==See also== * [[Volga–Don Canal]] which links the Caspian Sea and Sea of Azov for purposes of transportation.
==References== {{kml}} {{Reflist}} *[http://secure.britannica.com/ebc/article-9046399 Encyclopædia Britannica]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Kuma-Manych Canal}} [[Category:Irrigation in Russia]] [[Category:Canals in Russia]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Stavropol Krai]] [[Category:Canals opened in 1965]]

{{for|the lake in Italy|Verney Lake}} {{unreferenced|date=July 2011}} {{Infobox lake | name = Lac du Verney | image =Lac du Verney (38).jpg | caption =Lac du Verney | image_bathymetry = | caption_bathymetry = | location = [[France]] | coords = {{coord|45.138889|N|6.047222|E|region:FR_type:waterbody|display=inline,title}} | type = [[reservoir]] | inflow = L'[[Eau d'Olle]], & other small streams | outflow = [[Romanche|River Romanche]] | catchment = | basin_countries = [[Isère (département)|Isère]], ([[Rhône-Alpes]]) | length = | width = | area = | depth = | max-depth = | volume = | residence_time = | shore = | elevation = | islands = | cities = }}
'''Lac du Verney''' is an artificial reservoir in the department of [[Isère (département)|Isère]], in the [[Rhône-Alpes]] of [[France]]. It serves as the lower reservoir for the [[Grand'Maison Dam]] [[pumped-storage]] scheme.
Neighbouring lakeside communities include Oz and [[Allemond]].
Since 2006 it has hosted the opening swim of the [[Alpe d'Huez Triathlon]].
[[File:Barrage verney 02.jpg|thumb|none|280px|Dam wall of the Lac du Verney]]
{{Commons category|Lac du Verney}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Verney, Lake}} [[Category:Reservoirs in France]] [[Category:Dams in France]] [[Category:Lakes of Isère]]

{{Infobox lake | name = Lake Arenal | image = LagoArenal.jpg | caption = A view from the southwest side looking across at the north depth {{convert|30|-|60|m|abbr=on}} | pushpin_map = Costa Rica | pushpin_map_caption = Location in Costa Rica | coordinates = {{coord|10.505167|-84.872168|region:CR_type:waterbody|display=inline,title}} | max-depth = | volume = | residence_time = | shore = | elevation = | islands = | cities = | embedded = {{Designation list | embed = yes | designation1 = Ramsar | designation1_offname = Cuenca Embalse Arenal | designation1_date = 7 March 2000 | designation1_number = 1022<ref>{{Cite web|title=Cuenca Embalse Arenal|website=[[Ramsar Convention|Ramsar]] Sites Information Service|url=https://rsis.ramsar.org/ris/1022|accessdate=25 April 2018}}</ref>}} }}
'''Lake Arenal''' ({{lang-es|Lago Arenal}}) is a lake which is situated in the northern highlands of [[Costa Rica]]. It is currently the largest lake in [[Costa Rica]] at {{convert|85|sqkm|mi2|adj=on}}. Its depth varies between 30 and 60 meters (100–200 feet) seasonally.<ref>{{cite web|last=Stater|first=Adam|title=Lake Arenal Depth|url=http://www.anywherecostarica.com/attractions/national-park/lake-arenal}}</ref>
The town of Arenal was relocated to higher ground when the lake was expanded in 1979. The old towns of Arenal and Tronadora now lie abandoned at the bottom of the lake, with the new town of Arenal existing to the northeast on the lake.
== Hydroelectricity == Lake Arenal was tripled in size with the construction of the [[Presa Sangregado Dam|Arenal dam]] in 1979, which exists at the eastern end of the lake. This [[hydroelectric]] project is hugely important to Costa Rica, initially generating 70% of the country's electricity, now closer to 17%, and was also a driving force behind Costa Rica's green energy policy.<ref>{{Cite journal| first=Carlos | last=Pérez| coauthors=| contribution=Results of the Event| title=Minutes of the Workshop on Adaptation to Climate Change in Costa Rica| editor-first=| editor-last=| coeditors=| publisher=Trofcca Central America| place=San José, Costa Rica| pages=| date=2006-12-13| id= | contribution-url=http://www.cifor.cgiar.org/trofcca/america/workshops/wrkshp_adapt_costa_rica_Dec_2006.doc| format=DOC| accessdate=2007-10-02| postscript=<!--None--> }}</ref>
== Wildlife == Fish species in Lake Arenal the [[machaca (fish)|machaca]] and the [[rainbow bass]]. There are also many species of plants, 120 mammals (including [[jaguar]] and [[tapir]]), and 300 birds (including [[quetzal]]).
== Recreation == From November through April the strong, dependable winds attract windsurfers and kite surfers to its western end.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ticowind.com/ |title=Lake Arenal Costa Rica Tico Wind Windsurf Center - Windsurfing Kiteboarding Rentals Lessons |accessdate=2015-10-07 }}</ref> Many consider Lake Arenal one of the world's foremost windsurfing and kite surfing areas. Wakeboarding is gaining popularity in Costa Rica, with Lake Arenal being the center of this activity. Stand up paddling<ref>{{Cite web|title = Costa Rica Stand Up Paddling Tours|url = http://www.desafiocostarica.com/desafio-adventure-company-tours/all/stand-up-paddling|website = www.desafiocostarica.com|accessdate = 2016-01-04}}</ref> and kayaking are also popular activities for tourists visiting the lake's Eastern part near the earthen dam. There are many good fishing (primarily for rainbow bass) and now kayak fishing opportunities in the shallow and secluded coves. The area surrounding the lake has good hiking, biking, bird watching, and horseback riding opportunities.<ref>{{cite web|last=Stater|first=Adam|title=Lake Arenal Activities|url=http://www.anywherecostarica.com/attractions/national-park/lake-arenal}}</ref>
== Gallery ==
<gallery> File:Lac Arenal Costa Rica 003.JPG File:Lac_Arenal_Costa_Rica_Barrage.JPG|hydro-electricity on Lake Arenal. File:Eoliennes à Tierras Morenas_lac Arenal_Costa Rica.JPG|Wind power plant of Tierras Morenas, around Lake Arenal. File:Lake Arenal and Volcano.JPG File:Lake_Arenal_Kitesurfing.JPG File:Lake_Arenal_Windsurfer.JPG File:Arenal Lake.jpg|Horse grazing on the shore of the Lake with the Arenal Volcano in the background. File:Arenal Lake 2.jpg|View of the lake from the village of El Fosforo, on the southeastern shore. </gallery>
[[File:Arenal Volcano panorama.JPG|thumb|center|750px|Panorama of the area around Arenal Lake.]] [[File:Lake Arenal windsurf and kite surf beach at the Tico Wind peninsula.jpg|thumb|center|750px|Lake Arenal windsurf and kite surf beach at the Tico Wind peninsula]]

revision.text:
The '''National Children’s Study''' (NCS) was a longitudinal [[cohort study]] that planned to recruit participants from across the United States of America. It was intended to measure the many factors that contribute to [[health]] and disease from before birth through age 21. This included, but was not limited to, the search for drivers of diseases with prenatal or developmental origins. The Study was closed in December 2014.<ref name=Science121214>{{cite news|author1=Jocelyn Kaiser|title=NIH cancels massive U.S. children’s study|url=http://news.sciencemag.org/funding/2014/12/nih-cancels-massive-u-s-children-s-study|accessdate=December 16, 2014|work=Science|date=December 12, 2014|quote=has too many flaws to be carried out in a tight budget environment, advisers today told National Institutes of Health (NIH) Director Francis Collins. He announced he is dismantling the study immediately.}}</ref><ref name=NIH121214>{{cite web|author1=Francis S. Collins|authorlink1=Francis S. Collins|title=Statement on the National Children’s Study|url=http://www.nih.gov/about/director/12122014_statement_ACD.htm|website=hih.gov|publisher=NIH|accessdate=December 14, 2014|date=December 12, 2014|quote=I am appointing Dr. David Murray, NIH Associate Director for Prevention, effectively immediately, to manage the orderly transition of the NCS program office and closure of the study.}}</ref>
==Organization== The NCS was led by the [[National Institutes of Health]], with the [[Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development|''Eunice Kennedy Shriver'' National Institute of Child Health and Human Development]] (NICHD) serving as the scientific lead. Within NICHD, the NCS Program Office administered the implementation of day-to-day Study operations. The Program Office was supervised by the Study Director, Steven Hirschfeld, MD, PhD Associate Director for Clinical Research, NICHD.
For advice and recommendations regarding Study framework, content, and methodologies, the NCS Program Office engaged external advisors and scientific groups. These groups included federal partners such as the NCS Federal Advisory Committee and a Federal Consortium with representatives from multiple federal agencies including: the [[U.S. Department of Health and Human Services]], the [[National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences|National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences of the National Institutes of Health]], the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]], and the [[U.S. Environmental Protection Agency]]. An independent Study Monitoring and Oversight Committee monitored study progress and participant safety.
In addition to these more formal channels, the NCS solicited feedback from subject matter experts from around the world and from individuals, community advocates, and professional societies concerned with child health. The NCS Program Office also provided public forums for input on a variety of initiatives.<ref>http://www.nationalchildrensstudy.gov/about/organization/Pages/default.aspx</ref>
==Congressional Mandate== The "President’s Task Force on Health Risks and Safety Risks to Children" recommended this federal initiative in 1999, after which Congress passed the [[Children's Health Act]] of 2000 (Title X, Section 1004). The Act charged NICHD to:
# plan, develop, and implement a [[prospective cohort study]], from birth to adulthood, to evaluate the effects of both chronic and intermittent exposures on child health and human development; and # investigate basic mechanisms of developmental disorders and environmental factors, both risk and protective, that influence health and developmental processes.
The Act required this NCS to: # incorporate behavioral, emotional, educational, and contextual consequences to enable a complete assessment of the physical, chemical, biological, and psychosocial environmental influences on children’s well-being; # gather data on environmental influences and outcomes on diverse populations of children, which may include the consideration of prenatal exposures; and # consider health disparities among children, which may include the consideration of prenatal exposures<ref>National Institutes of Health [http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/FR-2011-05-02/html/2011-10500.htm New Proposed Collection; Comment Request; Neuropsychosocial Measures Formative Research Methodology Studies for the National Children's Study] Federal Register, vol 76, No. 84, May 2, 2011</ref>
==Objective== The NCS was designed to examine the effects of the environment—broadly defined to include factors such as air, water, diet, sound, family dynamics, community, and cultural influences— and [[genetics]] on the growth, [[child development|development]], and health of children across the United States. The NCS was designed to follow approximately 100,000 children, some from before birth, through age 21 years. The NCS planned to collect comprehensive information to: # contribute to improving the health and well-being of all children # deepen our understanding of the contribution of various factors to a range of health and disease outcomes # understand factors that lead to health disparities.
With this broad perspective, the NCS was designed to contribute to the implementation of health equity, where each individual has an opportunity to realize their health potential.<ref>http://www.nationalchildrensstudy.gov/about/overview/Pages/default.aspx</ref>
==Discontinued== The NCS was in its Vanguard, or [[pilot study|pilot]] phase, which was designed to assess the feasibility, acceptability, cost, and utility of Study scientific output, logistics, and operations prior to initiating the Main Study. The Vanguard Study enrolled about 5,000 children in 40 counties across the United States. General recruitment was completed in July 2013.
On December 12, 2014, the National Children’s Study closed, after an expert review committee advised the NIH Director that moving forward with the larger Main Study would not be the best way to add to the understanding of how environmental and genetic factors influence child health and development.<ref>National Children’s Study (NCS) Working Group [http://acd.od.nih.gov/reports/NCS_WG_FINAL_REPORT.pdf FINAL REPORT – DECEMBER 12, 2014] National Institutes of Health, Advisory Committee to the Director, 19 pages</ref>
The NCS will not collect any new information from participants.{{citation needed|date=April 2015}}
The NIH plans to make data already collected available to researchers in late 2015.{{citation needed|date=April 2015}}
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *{{official|http://www.nationalchildrensstudy.gov}} *Philip J. Landrigan, and Dean B. Baker [http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMp1500276?query=TOC The National Children's Study — End or New Beginning?] N Engl J Med 2015; 372:1486-1487 April 16, 2015 DOI: 10.1056/NEJMp1500276
[[Category:Children's health in the United States]] [[Category:Pediatrics in the United States]] [[Category:Environmental research]]

revision.text:
[[Image:Vladimir Putin 1 February 2008-7.jpg|thumb|[[President of Russia]] [[Vladimir Putin]] lays flowers, on 1 February 2008, at the memorial to the victims of the massacre.]]
The '''Novocherkassk massacre'''<ref>[http://soviethistory.org/index.php?page=subject&SubjectID=1961novocherkassk&Year=1961 1961: Novocherkassk Massacre] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110303225923/http://www.soviethistory.org/index.php?page=subject&SubjectID=1961novocherkassk&Year=1961 |date=2011-03-03 }}</ref> refers to events tied to the [[labor strike]] at a locomotive building plant in [[Novocherkassk]], a city in the [[Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic|Russian SFSR]], [[Soviet Union]]. The events eventually culminated into the protests of June 1–2, 1962 when reportedly 26 protesters were killed by [[Soviet Army]] troops, and 87 were wounded.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://bessmertnybarak.ru/article/ne_khvataet_deneg_na_myaso/|title=«Не хватает денег на мясо и колбасу, ешьте пирожки с ливером»|website=Бессмертный барак|access-date=2016-06-02}}</ref>
==History==
{{Eastern Bloc sidebar}}
The riots were a direct result of shortages of food and provisions, as well as the poor working conditions in the factory. The protest began on June 1 in the ''[[Semyon Budyonny|Budyonny]] Electric [[Locomotive]] Factory'', when workers from the [[foundry]] and [[forge]] shops stopped work after factory management refused to hear their complaints. The strike and attendant discussions had spread throughout the whole factory by noon.
The unrest began when [[Nikita Khrushchev]] raised the prices of meat and butter throughout the Soviet Union on June 1st. On the same day, as required by a separate economic plan, the minimum production quotas for each worker at the factory were increased,<ref>Vladislav Zubok and Constantine Pleshkov, ''Inside the Kremlin's Cold War: from Stalin to Khrushchev'', Harvard University Press, p. 262</ref> thereby effectively reducing pay rates.<ref name=Hosking>Hosking, Geoffrey. A History of the Soviet Union, [[Fontana Press]], [[London]]. 1992.</ref> This culminated in a march on the [[town hall]] and police headquarters, and the strike spread to other enterprises after police arrested thirty workers.
According to documents declassified in 90's, motorized infantry units were called to suppress the protesters, but they fired in the air, and the lethal fire came from a unit of [[Internal Troops of Russia|Internal troops]], from [[Rostov-on-Don]] composed of 10 snipers and 2 machine guns, who were set up at the "Don" hotel. Orders to kill were approved through the whole [[command hierarchy|chain of command]], from Khrushchev, through the ministry of defense.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://bessmertnybarak.ru/article/ne_khvataet_deneg_na_myaso/|title=«Не хватает денег на мясо и колбасу, ешьте пирожки с ливером»|work=Бессмертный барак|access-date=2018-06-04}}</ref>
The Commander of the North-Caucasian Troops, general [[Matvey Shaposhnikov|Kuzmich Shapochnikov]], refused to execute an order to attack peaceful demonstrators with tanks (he reportedly said, "I don't see any enemy that we could turn our weapons against"), for which he was later degraded and arrested.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://bessmertnybarak.ru/Shaposhnikov_Matvey_Kuzmich/|title=Шапошников Матвей Кузьмич - История на сайте Бессмертный барак|work=Шапошников Матвей Кузьмич :: Бессмертный барак|access-date=2018-06-04}}</ref>
According to now available official sources, 26 protesters were killed by the [[machine-gun]]-equipped<ref>[http://www.vesti.ru/doc.html?id=124198&cid=1&date=02.06.2007 (in Russian) Новочеркасск вспоминает жертв трагедии, Vest, 2007]</ref><ref>[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,827865,00.html And Then the Police Fired], ''[[TIME Magazine]]'', October 19, 1962</ref> Soviet Army troops, and 87 were wounded with 3 of those dying later of their wounds. After the initial demonstrations, a curfew was implemented in the town. The dead bodies were secretly buried in the cemeteries of other towns of the [[Rostov Oblast]]. However, the following morning, a large group of several hundred demonstrators again gathered in the square. One hundred and sixteen were arrested, of which fourteen were convicted by show trials, seven of those receiving a death sentence and were executed. The others were sentenced to prison terms of ten to fifteen years.<ref>[[Taubman, William]]. ''[[Khrushchev: The Man and His Era]]'', First Edition, [[W. W. Norton & Co.]], [[New York City|New York]], NY. 2003.</ref>
Following the incident, the Soviet government directed extra food supplies to the region and began an investigation. Additional arrests of workers followed, as did [[court martial|courts martial]] of military officials involved. [[Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn]] claimed that individuals wounded in the unrest and their families were exiled to [[Siberia]].
The whole story was never allowed to appear in the press or any other Soviet mass media and remained an official secret until 1992, when the remains of 20 bodies were recovered and identified in 1992 and buried in the cemetery of [[Novoshakhtinsk]].
== In fiction ==
During a Politburo scene in ''[[The Devil's Alternative]]'' (1979) by author [[Frederick Forsyth]], the [[Chairman of the KGB|KGB chief]], asked if he could suppress riots during famine, responds that the KGB could suppress ten, even twenty Novocherkassks, but not fifty – intentionally using the example to highlight how serious the difficulties would be that the Soviet Union finds itself in the novel.
The massacre is dramatized in [[Francis Spufford]]'s 2010 novel ''Red Plenty''.
==See also== {{portal|Russia|Sociology|History|Food}} *[[Kengir uprising]] * [[List of food riots]] *[[List of massacres in the Soviet Union]] *[[Vorkuta uprising]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.spunk.org/texts/places/russia/sp000197.txt The Novocherkassk Tragedy, June 1–3 1962] – An eyewitness account of the strike leading up to the shootings. {{Eastern Bloc}} {{coord|47.47|40.06|display=title}} [[Category:Mass murder in 1962]] [[Category:1962 riots]] [[Category:Massacres in the Soviet Union]] [[Category:1962 in the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Riots and civil disorder in the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Food riots]] [[Category:Massacres committed by the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Protests in the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Protest-related deaths]] [[Category:Novocherkassk]] [[Category:June 1962 events]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox U.S. legislation | name = Nutrition Labeling and Education Act of 1990 | fullname = To amend the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to prescribe nutrition labeling for foods, and for other purposes. | acronym = NLE Act, "NL&E Act" | enacted by = 101st | effective date = November 8, 1990 | public law url = http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/STATUTE-104/pdf/STATUTE-104-Pg2353.pdf | cite public law = 101-535 | cite statutes at large = {{usstat|104|2353}} | acts amended= [[Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act]] | title amended = [[Title 21 of the United States Code|21 U.S.C.: Food and Drugs]] | sections created= | sections amended= Chapter 9 § 301 | leghisturl = http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d101:H.R.3562: | introducedin = House | introducedbill = {{USBill|101|H.R.|3562}} | introducedby = [[Henry Waxman]] ([[Democratic Party (United States)|D]]–[[California|CA]]) | introduceddate = October 31, 1989 | committees = [[United States House Committee on Energy and Commerce|House Committee on Energy and Commerce]] | passedbody1 = House | passeddate1 = July 30, 1990 | passedvote1 = passed voice vote | passedbody2 = Senate | passeddate2 = October 24, 1990 | passedvote2 = passed voice vote | conferencedate= | passedbody3 = | passeddate3 = | passedvote3 = | agreedbody3 = House | agreeddate3 = October 26, 1990 | agreedvote3 = passed voice vote | agreedbody4= <!-- used if agreedbody3 further amends legislation --> | agreeddate4= <!-- used if agreedbody3 further amends legislation --> | agreedvote4= <!-- used if agreedbody3 further amends legislation --> | passedbody4= | passeddate4= | passedvote4= | signedpresident= [[George H. W. Bush]] | signeddate= November 8, 1990 | amendments= | SCOTUS cases =''[[New York State Restaurant Association v. New York City Board of Health]]'' }} The '''Nutrition Labeling and Education Act''' (NLEA) (Public Law 101-535) is a 1990 [[United States]] Federal law. It was signed into law on November 8, 1990 by President [[George H. W. Bush]].<ref name = "AHA"/>
The law gives the [[Food and Drug Administration]] (FDA) authority to require nutrition labeling of most foods regulated by the Agency; and to require that all nutrient content claims (for example, 'high fiber', 'low fat', etc.) and health claims meet FDA regulations.<ref name="FDA">{{cite journal |title=Nutritional Labeling |journal=[[United States]] [[Food and Drug Administration]] |url=//www.fda.gov/ora/inspect_ref/igs/nleatxt.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071014014547/http://www.fda.gov/ora/inspect_ref/igs/nleatxt.html |archivedate=October 14, 2007 |df= }}</ref> The act did not require [[restaurant]]s to comply with the same standards.
The regulations became effective for health claims, ingredient declarations, and percent juice labeling on May 8, 1993 (but percent juice labeling was exempted until May 8, 1994).<ref name = "FDA"/>
Effective Jan. 1, 2006, the Nutrition Facts Labels on packaged food products are required by the FDA to list how many grams of [[trans fatty acid]] (trans fat) are contained within one serving of the product.<ref name = "AHA">{{cite journal | title = Nutrition Labeling AHA Advocacy Position | journal =[[American Heart Association]] | url =http://www.americanheart.org/presenter.jhtml?identifier=4631 }}</ref>
==Dietary Supplement Act of 1992== Senator [[Orrin Hatch]] of Utah introduced the [[Health Freedom Act]] of 1992 which would have blocked the FDA from using health claims as a reason to regulate dietary supplements as drugs. The senator said he "entered the controversy after hearing from constituents in his home state, including both consumers and makers of dietary supplements". Hatch stated that the FDA "can put anybody out of business if they want to." Hatch's bill did not get very far, but it encouraged Congress to pass the [[Dietary Supplement Act]] of 1992 (Public Law 102-571), which blocked the FDA from applying its forthcoming labeling rules for conventional foods to dietary supplements for another year, until the end of 1993.<ref name = "pol">{{cite book | last =Nestle | first = Marion | year = 2002 | title = Food Politics | publisher =University of California Press | isbn = 0-520-24067-7 }} p. 255</ref><ref name = "NYT">{{cite journal | first = Lena| last =Williams | date =August 9, 1992 | title = F.D.A. Steps Up Effort to Control Vitamin Claims | journal =New York Times | url =https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E0CE4DA1F38F93AA3575BC0A964958260&sec=health&spon=&pagewanted=2 }} Source of quotes.</ref>
The [[Nutritional Health Alliance]], an industry lobby group,<ref name = "sci">{{cite journal | first = Susan Katz| last = Miller| date =August 7, 1993 | title = The return of the medicine show| journal =New Scientist | url =https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg13918851.800-the-return-of-the-medicine-show-.html }}</ref> claimed credit for getting the [[Dietary Supplement Act]] of 1992 passed.<ref name = "pol"/>
==See also== *[[Dietary Supplement Health and Education Act of 1994]] *[[Food Guide Pyramid]] *[[New York State Restaurant Association v. New York City Board of Health]]
==Notes== <references/>
==External links== * {{cite web |url=http://www.fda.gov/Food/IngredientsPackagingLabeling/FoodAdditivesIngredients/ |title=Food Additives & Ingredients |work=Ingredients, Packaging & Labeling |publisher=U.S. Food and Drug Administration }} * {{cite web |url=http://www.fda.gov/Food/IngredientsPackagingLabeling/LabelingNutrition/ucm2006873.htm |title=Label Claims |work=Ingredients, Packaging & Labeling |series=Labeling & Nutrition |publisher= |location=U.S. Food and Drug Administration }} * {{cite web |url=http://www.fda.gov/Food/IngredientsPackagingLabeling/LabelingNutrition/ |title=Labeling & Nutrition |work=Ingredients, Packaging & Labeling |publisher=U.S. Food and Drug Administration }} * {{cite web |url=http://www.fda.gov/Food/IngredientsPackagingLabeling/LabelingNutrition/ucm20026097.htm |title=Nutrition Facts Label Programs & Materials |work=Ingredients, Packaging & Labeling |series=Labeling & Nutrition |publisher=U.S. Food and Drug Administration }} * [https://www.fastcase.com/Google/Start.aspx?C=a0f307aef1167c3b561e32f4a3419cf7abe12c76e1936c53&D=9cd54d1cf1c4371dd493e8d72bae503ccf8568621d266fd4 Nutritional Health Alliance v. Shalala], 953 F.Supp. 526 (S.D.N.Y., 1997) Challenge, on First Amendment grounds, the NLEA framework requiring advanced FDA authorization for health claims made on vitamin labels.

revision.comment: updated the treatment section with evidence from the cochrane review 2018 information about prevention options for occupational hand irritant dermatitis
revision.text:
'''Occupational skin diseases''' are ranked among the top five occupational diseases in many countries.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Kanerva's Occupational Dermatology|last=|first=|publisher=|year=|isbn=978-3-642-02035-3|location=|pages=}}</ref>
[[Contact dermatitis|Contact Dermatitis]] due to irritation is [[inflammation]] of the skin which results from a contact with an irritant.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Irritant Dematitis|last=|first=|publisher=|year=|isbn=978-3-540-31294-9|location=|pages=}}</ref> It has been observed that this type of [[dermatitis]] does not require prior sensitization of the [[immune system]]. There have been studies to support that past or present [[Atopic dermatitis|atopic]] [[Atopic dermatitis|dermatitis]] is a risk factor for this type of [[dermatitis]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Coenraads|first=P. J.|last2=Diepgen|first2=T. L.|date=1998-02-01|title=Risk for hand eczema in employees with past or present atopic dermatitis|journal=International Archives of Occupational and Environmental Health|volume=71|issue=1|pages=7–13|issn=0340-0131|pmid=9523243|doi=10.1007/s004200050243}}</ref> Common irritants include detergents, acids, alkalies, oils, organic solvents and reducing agents.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Elsner|first=P.|date=1994-07-01|title=Irritant dermatitis in the workplace|journal=Dermatologic Clinics|volume=12|issue=3|pages=461–467|issn=0733-8635|pmid=7923942}}</ref>
The acute form of this dermatitis develops on exposure of the skin to a strong irritant or caustic chemical. This exposure can occur as a result of [[accident]] at a [[workplace]] . The irritant reaction starts to increase in its intensity within minutes to hours of exposure to the irritant and reaches its peak quickly. After the reaction has reached its peak level, it starts to heal. This process is known as decrescendo phenomenon.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Dermatotoxicology|last=|first=|publisher=|year=|isbn=978-0849397738|location=|pages=}}</ref> The most frequent potent irritants leading to this type of dermatitis are acids and alkaline solutions.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Eichmann|first=A.|last2=Amgwerd|first2=D.|date=1992-05-05|title=[Toxic contact dermatitis]|journal=Schweizerische Rundschau Für Medizin Praxis = Revue Suisse De Médecine Praxis|volume=81|issue=19|pages=615–617|issn=1013-2058|pmid=1589676}}</ref> The symptoms include redness and swelling of the skin along with the formation of blisters.
The chronic form occurs as a result of repeated exposure of the skin to weak irritants over long periods of time.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dahl|first=M. V.|date=1988-01-01|title=Chronic, irritant contact dermatitis: mechanisms, variables, and differentiation from other forms of contact dermatitis|journal=Advances in Dermatology|volume=3|pages=261–275|issn=0882-0880|pmid=3152823}}</ref>
Clinical manifestations of the contact dermatitis are also modified by external factors such as environmental factors (mechanical pressure, temperature, and humidity) and predisposing characteristics of the individual (age, sex, ethnic origin, preexisting skin disease, atopic skin diathesis, and anatomic region exposed.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ccohs.ca/oshanswers/diseases/dermatitis.html|title=Dermatitis, Irritant Contact : OSH Answers|last=Safety|first=Government of Canada, Canadian Centre for Occupational Health and|website=www.ccohs.ca|access-date=2016-03-25}}</ref>
Another occupational skin disease is glove-related hand [[urticaria]], believed to be caused by repeated wearing and removal of the gloves. It has been reported as an occupational problem among the health care workers. The reaction is caused by the latex or the [[nitrile]] present in the gloves.<ref>Glove-related hand urticaria: an increasing occupational problem amongst health care workers. Hawkey S, Abdul Ghaffar S.</ref>
==Prevention==
Prevention measures include avoidance of the irritant through its removal from the workplace or through technical shielding by the use of potent irritants in closed systems or automation, irritant replacement or removal <ref>{{Cite book|title=handbook of occupational dermatology|last=|first=|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> and personal protection of the workers. Low quality evidence exists for the effectiveness of certain therapies and their ability to specifically prevent hand skin irritation in the workplace. The limited evidence that does exist suggests that moisturizers used alone or in combination with a barrier cream can result in a clinically beneficial effect in the long or short-term primary prevention of occupational irritant hand dermatitis.<ref>Bauer A, Rönsch H, Elsner P, Dittmar D, Bennett C, Schuttelaar MA, Lukács J, John S, Williams HC. Interventions for preventing occupational irritant hand dermatitis. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2018, Issue 4. Art. No.: CD004414. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD004414.pub3</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Occupational safety and health]] [[Category:Cutaneous conditions]]

revision.comment: /* Context */Philip Morris International is not apart of Altria Group. Philip Morris USA is apart of Altria Group. The case is for Philip Morris International not Philip Morris USA.
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2017}} {{Use British English|date=December 2017}} {{Infobox Court Case |name = Philip Morris v. Uruguay |court = [[International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes|ICSID]] |image = World Bank building at Washington.jpg |imagesize = 200px |caption = Office [[International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes|ICSID]] in 2006. |full name=ARB/10/7. Philip Morris Brand Sàrl (Switzerland), Philip Morris Products S.A. (Switzerland) v. Oriental Republic of Uruguay |transcripts = [https://medios.presidencia.gub.uy/tav_portal/2016/noticias/NO_U130/laudo_spa1.pdf Sentence links] |judges = Gary Born, James Crawford, Piero Bernardini |date decided = 8 July 2016 (6 years old) |keywords = [[Cigarettes]], [[intellectual property]], [[health]] }}
The '''Philip Morris v. Uruguay case''' ({{lang-es|'''Caso Philip Morris contra Uruguay'''}}) started on 19 February 2010, when the multinational [[tobacco company]] [[Philip Morris International]] filed a complaint against [[Uruguay]].<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.espectador.com/1v4_contenido.php?id=176011&sts=1 |title = Philip Morris versus Uruguay |author = El Espectador |date = 9 March 2010 |accessdate = 15 November 2010 |language = Spanish |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100314160056/http://www.espectador.com/1v4_contenido.php?id=176011&sts=1 |archivedate = 14 March 2010 |df = dmy-all }}</ref> The company complains that Uruguay's [[smoking ban|anti-smoking legislation]] devalues its cigarette trademarks and investments in the country and is suing Uruguay for compensation under the [[bilateral investment treaty]] between Switzerland and Uruguay.<ref name=bbc/> (Philip Morris is headquartered in [[Lausanne]].)<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.pmi.com/marketpages/pages/market_en_ch.aspx | title =Philip Morris International Management SA - Switzerland Operations Centre | author = [[Philip Morris International|PMI]] | accessdate = 15 November 2010}}</ref>
The treaty provides that disputes are settled by binding [[arbitration]] before the [[International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes]] (ICSID).<ref>{{cite web | url=http://abcnews.go.com/Business/wireStory/uruguay-wins-dispute-tobacco-giant-philip-morris-40448855 | title=Uruguay Wins Dispute With Tobacco Giant Philip Morris | work=ABC News | date=8 July 2016 | author=AP | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160709143704/http://abcnews.go.com/Business/wireStory/uruguay-wins-dispute-tobacco-giant-philip-morris-40448855 | archive-date=2016-07-09 | access-date=23 October 2016 | dead-url=yes}}</ref>
Uruguay had received accolades from the [[World Health Organization]] and from anti-smoking activists for its [[Tobacco control|anti-smoking campaign]].<ref>{{cite web| url =http://www.elobservador.com.uy/noticia/208683/cigarrillos-mentolados-aumentan-la-adiccion/|title = Cigarrillos mentolados aumentan la adicción|author = El Observador |date = 6 September 2011|accessdate =13 September 2011 |language = Spanish}}</ref>
On 8 July 2016, after 6 years, the [[International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes|ICSID]] ruled in favor of Uruguay, forcing the demandant to pay the expenses of the defendants and the court.<ref>{{cite web| url =http://www.elpais.com.uy/informacion/fallo-favorable-uruguay-juicio-philip-morris.html |title =Philip Morris deberá pagar a Uruguay US$ 7 millones por gastos judiciales|author = [[El País (Uruguay)|El País]]|language = Spanish}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url =http://www.bbc.com/mundo/noticias-america-latina-36752509|title =Histórico fallo a favor de Uruguay en el juicio contra la tabacalera Philip Morris|author =BCC |language = Spanish}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url =http://www.elfinanciero.com.mx/economia/esta-es-la-historia-de-uruguay-david-contra-philip-morris-goliath.html |title =Esta es la historia de Uruguay (David) contra Philip Morris (Goliath) |author =elfinanciero|language = Spanish}}</ref>
== Context == [[File:Cigarette_packet_foil.JPG|150px|right|thumb|Cigarette box of the company Philip Morris.]] [[File:Flag of Uruguay.svg|150px|right]]
On 19 June 2003, when the Uruguayan President was [[Jorge Batlle]], the [[General Assembly of Uruguay]] approved the [[Framework Convention on Tobacco Control]], an agreement whereby Policies recommended by the [[World Health Organization]] were implemented.
In 2006, Uruguay under President [[Tabaré Vázquez]], an [[oncologist]] by profession, began to enact comprehensive [[smoking ban|anti-smoking legislation]]. On 1 March 2006, Uruguay became the first country in [[Latin America]] to prohibit smoking in enclosed public spaces.<ref>{{cite web| url =http://www.lr21.com.uy/comunidad/461696-uruguay-cree-que-philip-morris-incumplio-pasos-previos-a-la-demanda| title = Uruguay cree que Philip Morris incumplió pasos previos a la demanda |author =LR21| date =9 July 2011|accessdate =4 August 2011|language = Spanish}}</ref> In March 2008 the legislature approved Law 18.256 <ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.parlamento.gub.uy/leyes/AccesoTextoLey.asp?Ley=18256&Anchor|title = Ley Nº 18.256 Control del Tabaquismo|author = Uruguay Legislature|date = 6 March 2008|accessdate = 10 March 2009|language = Spanish|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140416104642/http://www.parlamento.gub.uy/leyes/AccesoTextoLey.asp?Ley=18256&Anchor|archivedate = 16 April 2014|df = dmy-all}}</ref> which includes six strategies of anti-smoking policy.
Some of the measures by the government were the ban on selling different types of presentations of the same brand of cigarettes, the dissemination of images warning about the risks of smoking and covering at least 80% of the cigarette pack, raising of taxes, banning cigarette advertising in the media, and banning sponsorship of sports events. In addition, smoking was banned in public places such as offices, student centers, bars, restaurants, dances and public places, among others.
The smokefree campaign "Libre de Humo de Tabaco" was gradually implemented by the "Ministerio de Salud Pública del Uruguay" ([[List of Ministers for Public Health (Uruguay)|Ministry of Public Health of Uruguay]]).<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.msp.gub.uy/uc_546_1.html|title = Campaña "Libre de Humo de Tabaco"|author = MSP|accessdate = 15 November 2010|language = Spanish|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100615005816/http://www.msp.gub.uy/uc_546_1.html|archivedate = 15 June 2010|df = dmy-all}}</ref>
== Complaint ==
[[Philip Morris International]] is a multinational company, a leading producer of cigarettes, of which it owns seven out of twenty global brands.
The tobacco company initiated a claim in the [[International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes]] (ICSID), a part of the [[World Bank]] seeking $25 million in compensation from Uruguay.<ref>{{cite web|author1=[[Alfred-Maurice de Zayas]]|title=How can Philip Morris sue Uruguay over its tobacco laws?|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2015/nov/16/philip-morris-uruguay-tobacco-isds-human-rights|website=The Guardian|accessdate=22 October 2016|date=16 November 2015}}</ref> In that forum, an arbitration tribunal was formed with one arbitrator appointed by each party and a third arbitrator elected by the arbitrators appointed by the parties. The plaintiffs are FTR Holding SA (Switzerland), Philip Morris Products SA (Switzerland) and Abal Hermanos SA (PMI representative in Uruguay) against Uruguay (ICSID Case No. ARB/10/7).<ref>{{cite web|url = http://icsid.worldbank.org/ICSID/FrontServlet|title = ICSID - Case Details|author = [[International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes|ICSID]]|date = 26 March 2010|accessdate =17 November 2010}}</ref>
{{Quote |"''We have no choice but to litigate''" said Rees. The company said it has sought to dialogue with the government without success.<ref name=bbc>{{cite web|url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/mundo/economia/2010/03/100312_uruguay_tabacaleras_philip_morris_demanda_estado_jp.shtml| title = Tabacalera Philip Morris demanda a Uruguay |author = [[British Broadcasting Corporation|BBC]]|date = 12 March 2010 |accessdate = 15 November 2010|language = Spanish}}</ref>|Morgan Rees, Director Communications Regulatory Philip Morris International, in 2010.}}
{{Quote |"''Philip Morris'' (which sued Uruguay for its anti smoking measures) ''wants to make an example to Uruguay and intimidate other countries''."<ref>{{cite web|url =https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hCgOmyRviMOvZIDa7TXoTwyoZtIg?docId=CNG.371586affc56793778e3f8ab1c8ee273.1b1|title = Philip Morris quiere dar un "escarmiento" a Uruguay, acusa ex presidente| date = 15 November 2010|author = [[Agence France-Presse|AFP]]|accessdate = 10 March 2009|language = Spanish}}</ref>| [[Tabaré Vázquez]], November 2010.}}
Philip Morris has filed similar cases against [[Norway]] and [[Australia]].
== Decision == On 2 July 2013, the tribunal decided it had jurisdiction.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.italaw.com/sites/default/files/case-documents/italaw1531.pdf |title =Decision on Jurisdiction |date=4 July 2013|accessdate=22 August 2014}}</ref>
The resolution of the case, which affected international [[jurisprudence]], took 6 years; the case ended on 8 July 2016. The [[World Bank]] [ICSID] ruled in favor of Uruguay, forcing the demandant to pay the costs of the defendants and the court. The final report established that [[Philip Morris International|Philip Morris]] had to pay 7 million [[dollars]] to the country for judicial expenses, in addition to paying different amounts for the fees and administrative expenses of the three arbitrators and the CADI.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.elpais.com.uy/informacion/fallo-favorable-uruguay-juicio-philip-morris.html|title = Philip Morris deberá pagar a Uruguay US$ 7 millones por gastos judiciales|author = [[El País (Uruguay)|El País]]|language = Spanish}}</ref> [[Gary Born]] emitted a discordant decision in two of the points of the judicial failure.
After its victory in the case, the government declared that from 2017 cigarettes in Uruguay will be sold in [[Plain tobacco packaging|generic packaging]].<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.elobservador.com.uy/a-partir-2017-los-cigarrillos-se-venderan-empaquetado-generico-n940912 |title =A partir de 2017 los cigarrillos se venderán en empaquetado genérico |author= El Observador|language = Spanish}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.teledoce.com/telemundo/nacionales/vazquez-anuncio-en-cadena-nacional-que-uruguay-gano-juicio-a-philips-morris/|title= Vázquez anunció en cadena nacional que Uruguay ganó juicio a Philips Morris|author = Canal 12|language = Spanish}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url =http://www.lr21.com.uy/politica/1302400-tabare-vazquez-aclaro-prohibicion-fumar-areas-publica-cerradas-incluye-marihuana |title = Drogas|author = LR21|language = Spanish}}</ref>
== Reactions == [[File:Carissa Etienne 2015.jpg|thumb|120px|[[Carissa Etienne]] in 2015.]] The [[World Health Organization]] (WHO) and the [[Pan American Health Organization]] (PAHO) supported Uruguay.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.paho.org/hq/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=12322&Itemid=135&lang=en|title=PAHO WHO {{!}} PAHO supports Uruguay in litigation filed by industry against tobacco control measures|last=|first=|date=|website=PAHO supports Uruguay in litigation filed by industry against tobacco control measures|publisher=Pan American Health Organization|access-date=2016-09-01}}</ref> Uruguay's anti-smoking efforts also received support from past [[Mayor of New York City|New York City Mayor]] [[Michael Bloomberg]],<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.espectador.com/1v4_contenido.php?id=198277&sts=1|title = Alcalde de Nueva York apoyó a Mujica en caso Philip Morris|author = El Espectador|date = 15 November 2010|accessdate = 16 November 2010|language = Spanish|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110417035205/http://www.espectador.com/1v4_contenido.php?id=198277&sts=1|archivedate = 17 April 2011|df = dmy-all}}</ref> and from Bernard Borel, Swiss deputy from the [[Canton of Vaud]].<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.larepublica.com.uy/politica/444836-suiza-apoya-a-uruguay | title = Suiza apoya a Uruguay |author = La República | date = 19 March 2010 | accessdate = 21 April 2011|language = Spanish}}</ref>
PAHO made a statement praising the decision: {{Quote |"''This decision is an acknowledgment of Uruguay's continued efforts to protect its population from tobacco use and tobacco smoke from others.''"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.paho.org/hq/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=12273%3Apaho-congratulates-uruguay-for-defending-tobacco-control-policies-against-tobacco-industry&Itemid=1926&lang=es | title = OMS y OPS felicitan a Uruguay por su victoria ante Philip Morris |author= [[Organización Mundial de la Salud|OPS]]|language = Spanish}}</ref> |Carissa Etienne, Director of the [[Pan American Health Organization]], August 2016.}}
== Effects ==
According to Enrico Bonadio, Senior Lecturer in Law at [[City University London]], the ruling in the case "may make it more difficult for tobacco companies to use lawsuits to produce a “[[chilling effect]]” and so discourage countries from introducing tobacco control policies."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://theconversation.com/uruguays-victory-against-big-tobacco-is-more-than-just-a-local-triumph-62319|title=Uruguay's victory against Big Tobacco is more than just a local triumph|author= theconversation|access-date=2016-07-31}}</ref>
== See also == {{Portal|law|Uruguay}} *[[Smoking in Uruguay]]
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == {{wikiquote}} {{commonscat|Caso Philip Morris contra Uruguay|Caso Philip Morris contra Uruguay}} {{SPATRAcite|es:Caso Philip Morris contra Uruguay|oldid=|5/2013}}
